misconceptions.name: Solved an unrelated acceleration problem instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program is written to compute average acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time, instead of reading five integers and summing only the even ones as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment is to read v0, v1, and t from the user and compute the average acceleration (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt for and read exactly five integers, use a loop to process them, check each with n % 2 == 0 to see if it is even, accumulate the sum of the even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for "v0, v1, and t" instead of five integers.
Reads three double values instead of five integers.
Computes (finalVelocity - startingVelocity) / timeElapsed instead of a sum.
No loop over five inputs is present.
No conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0) is present.
No accumulator variable is used to sum even values.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between this problem and a different physics-style exercise, or reuse of an acceleration example without adapting it to the current specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and redesign the program to: (1) read five integers, (2) loop over the inputs, (3) use n % 2 == 0 to detect even numbers, (4) keep a running sum of the even values, and (5) print the final sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All identifiers, prompt text, input types, and the main formula correspond to an acceleration calculation and show no attempt to implement the required sum-of-evens behavior.

evidence.note: This code reads three doubles (v0, v1, t) and computes average acceleration, with no handling of five integers, no loop, and no summing of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Submitted code for completely different problem (Acceleration Calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code designed to calculate average acceleration using three double inputs (v0, v1, t), which is entirely unrelated to the requested task of reading five integers and calculating the sum of the even ones. No part of the rubric requirements (reading 5 integers, using a loop, conditional checks for parity, or accumulating the sum) was met.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for a different assignment or copied an unrelated template, failing to address any requirements of the 'Sum of Even Numbers' problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted code should have included a mechanism (like a loop) to iterate 5 times, read an integer in each iteration, check if the integer is even using the modulus operator, and accumulate the sum of those even numbers.
symptoms: Program input prompts for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of '5 integers'
Input is read as doubles instead of integers
The calculation involves division of velocities and time elapsed
Output reports 'The average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the assignment requirements or incorrect submission management (submitting code written for another problem).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure the submitted code directly addresses the prompt: read 5 integers, use a conditional statement (if statement with modulus operator) to check for even numbers, and use an accumulator variable to store the final result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly implements the acceleration formula and associated input/output, which confirms that the student solved a different engineering/physics problem than the requested programming problem.

evidence.note: The class name suggests the code's purpose is calculating acceleration, not summing even numbers.
Reads 3 double inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integer inputs.
Calculation is for acceleration, not accumulation of even numbers.

Code only handles a fixed set of 3 inputs
No iteration mechanism
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted completely different code, suggesting they did not attempt to solve the assigned problem.

misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code has zero loop structures; this is objectively absent.

misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic to check for even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student's code contains no conditional statement to check if a number is even. The modulo operator (%) is not used, which is essential for this task.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task doesn't require checking divisibility or filtering values.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To filter even numbers, use a conditional: if (n % 2 == 0). The modulo operator returns the remainder of division; if remainder is 0, the number is even.
symptoms: No if statements in the code
No modulo operations (%)
All inputs treated the same way
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for a different problem (acceleration calculation) that doesn't require conditional filtering.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add an if statement with the condition (n % 2 == 0) to check if each number is even before adding to the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code completely lacks any conditional logic for even/odd checking.

evidence.note: No conditional logic present; calculation does not involve modulo or any filtering based on number properties

misconceptions.name: Wrong algorithm entirely; no sum accumulation
misconceptions.description: Instead of accumulating the sum of even numbers, the code calculates and prints average acceleration. No accumulator variable is used.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task is to calculate average acceleration from three velocity and time values.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires accumulating (adding up) only the even numbers from 5 input integers and printing their total sum, not calculating acceleration.

Uses subtraction and division instead of addition
No sum variable or accumulator pattern
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code from an entirely different assignment involving physics calculations rather than the sum-of-even-numbers problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Create a sum variable initialized to 0. Inside the loop, add each even number to this sum. After the loop, print the final sum value.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly calculates acceleration using a completely different formula and algorithm than required.

evidence.note: Prints acceleration instead of sum of even numbers; demonstrates fundamental misalignment with the problem
